questions.question_text: Which Network and Security virtualization solution provides network hybridity and mobility?

discussion.content:
B is correct:
• NSX Data Center is an end-to-end platform for data center networking.
• NSX Cloud extends the data center network into the public cloud, such as VMware Cloud on AWS or Microsoft Azure Cloud. NSX Cloud also provides container or Kubernetes support with VMware Enterprise PKS.
• NSX Intelligence is a distributed analytics solution that provides visibility and dynamic security policy enforcement for NSX-T Data Center environments.
• NSX Distributed IDS/IPS is an advanced threat detection engine purpose-built to detect lateral threat movement on east-west network traffic across multicloud environments.
• NSX Advanced Load Balancer enables you to deliver multicloud application services such as load balancing, application, security, autoscaling, container networking, and web application firewall.
• NSX Service Mesh enables discovery and secure communication of microservices in a heterogeneous infrastructure.
• VMware HCX delivers application and network hybridity and mobility (question 78)

comments.content: HCX is not a security tool at all... it's for migrations. Are you sure?

I believe B, HCX is the correct answer...not that it's a security tool, but a virtualization solution. If you peek through some of the datasheet (https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/products/hcx/vmw-hcx-application-migration-and-mobility-platform.pdf) and the main site (https://www.vmware.com/products/hcx.html), they respectively touch on mobility and security policies across your hybrid (on-prem, cloud, both, whatever) environments.

Remember - some of the questions historically have somewhat smelled of sales pitches from time to time.

questions.question_text: What are three characteristics of a transport zone? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABE
A,B, and E (you have to chose transport zone to be able to create a segment -not optional-, and in the transport zone you are NOT specifying any vds type -mainly you specify if the zone is overlay or vlan-)

A & B are correct. 

VDS is tricky bc it depends on the TZ type:
"Follow these guidelines during configuration:
• N-VDS or VDS can attach to only a single overlay transport zone. 
• N-VDS or VDS can attach to multiple VLAN transport zones."

Selected Answer: ABE
- A and E are definitely both correct
- C is out of question, TZ can only be mapped to a single N-DVS
- B or D, I am not too sure , but B is closer to the truth than D. TN scope is NOT defined by a given TZ because TN can belong to multiple TZs, unless it happens to belong to a single TZ. Meanwhile, a Segment will always be tied to a TZ, if not defined it will be tied to the default one (i.e. Overlay TZ).

Per my training guide from the vmware class: 
A transport node switch can be configured in the following ways: • 
- Transport nodes can be configured to use either N-VDS or VDS switches. 
- Transport nodes can be configured with multiple switches. 

So seems like C would be correct.
Did anyone try configuring a single ESXi Transport node, adding 2 N-VDSs, and assigning the same Overlay TZ? Then it appears successful, with 2 TEP IP addresses.
For me is ABE

comments.content: You can't create a Segment without a transport Zone. If you choose no transport Zone, it will be created with the default Overlay Transport Zone. You can't delete the default transport zone. So technical its not possible to create a segment without a transport zone

questions.question_text:
A user is assigned these two roles in NSX Manager:
✑ LB Admin
✑ Network Engineer
What privileges does this user have in the system?
How is the intra-tier transit link connection created between SR and DR for a Tier-0 Gateway?

discussion.content:
Answer B seems correct.

Found in the ICM 4.0 book : 

"The intratier TransitLink connection is also created when a service router is created. It is an internal logical switch between the distributed and service routers on a gateway. By default, the intratier TransitLink has an IP address in the 169.254.0.0/24 subnet range.
"

Selected Answer: B
Here's how I understand this one: 

A. Manually create a gateway interface and mark it as transit. - No, it's automatic. Cross off "A"

B. Automatically created when SR is initialized. - Yes, this is how it happens. SR is initialized and talks to the DR. 

C. Automatically created when DR is created. How? DR's can exist without SRs... seems silly. 

D. Manually create external uplink interface and mark it as transit. - No, it's automatic

Process of elimination yields "B".
B is correct

choices.B: Automatically created when SR is initialized.
choices.D: Manually create external uplink interface and mark it as transit.
choices.C: Automatically created when DR is created.
choices.A: Manually create a gateway interface and mark it as transit.
